We're back to our once-quarterly theme of "no one has a clue how to forecast oil company earnings any more".

BE

Shell's a beat, by a mile. BP isn't, by a mile. Why? Because (sellside) analysts are rubbish, that's why.

11:11 am
BE

Let's start with Shell though.

BE

You'll remember for Q2 expectations were considerably too high. Perhaps not surprisingly, Q3 expectations were set considerably too low.

BE

Upstream and downstream both beat.

11:13 am
BE

Expenses lower, free cashflow generally reassuring. If you want a big picture, it's perhaps that in the early evidence that BG purchase isn't going wrong yet.

BE

Here's Barclays to say exactly that.

BE

The acquisition of BG has created a number of uncertainties for Shell and 3Q was always set to be an important gauge of progress following what had been a poor set of 2Q numbers. In the end clean CCS net income of $2.8bn was more than 60% ahead of a Vara compiled consensus number and double our own expectations. Downstream performed well across both oil products and chemicals but the main turnaround came from the upstream which posted a small profit compared to a $1.3bn loss a quarter ago. More important than the earnings perhaps is the evolution of cash flow which was 3.7x the 2Q level on a reported basis. This combined with the CEO statement that underlying operational costs in 2016 are already at an annualized run-rate of $40bn (the level expected for the end of the year), the indication that capex will be at the low end of the $25-30bn range given in June and that the group is working on 16 material asset sales should prove enough to reassure investors that Shell is well on its way to resetting the business post the BG deal. We expect the release to have positive implications for the shares and rate the stock Overweight with a 2600p price target.

11:14 am
BE

Key points:

· At the net line, 3Q adjusted net income of $2.8bn was 63% ahead of Vara-compiled consensus and double our forecast, mainly driven by the strong beat at the operating level.

· At the operating line, results came in 54% ahead of consensus driven by a surprisingly strong upstream income of $4m versus consensus forecast of $803m loss. This coupled with the 18% beat of the downstream division more than offset the 11% miss by integrated gas.

· Downstream proved to be more resilient than expected given the move in refining margins with operating income 18% ahead of consensus and 19% higher than our forecast.

· Production for the quarter of 3,595kboe/d was 4% higher than our forecast and up 2% q/q.

· Cash flow from operations of $8.5bn was down 24% y/y. There was a release of working capital in the quarter partially offset by a negative inventory effect of $669m; excluding this we estimate adjusted cash flow from operations of $7.8bn, up 18% y/y, broadly in line with the move in clean earnings.

· Cash capex for 3Q of $5.3bn was down 18% y/y while the YTD figure including the BG acquisition of $16.4bn was down 13% y/y.

· With cash dividends of $2.7bn in 3Q, there was positive net free cash flow post capex and dividends.

· $3.8bn of dividends distributed to shareholders in the quarter, of which 29% was settled under the Scrip Dividend Programme.

· Net debt of $77.8bn in 3Q increased slighted q/q. Hence, gearing (net debt to capital) of 29.2% was up 1.1pp q/q.

· Shell highlighted that the integration of BG is now essentially done and has been completed well ahead of plan.

· Underlying opex run rate for 2016 reiterated at $40bn.

· Opex decreased by $0.6bn y/y to $10bn of which $0.4bn related to redundancy and restructuring and $0.4bn related to a provision.

· Organic capex guidance for 2016 unchanged at $29bn including $3bn of non-cash items. Capex for 2017 confirmed to be around $25bn, at the low end of $25-30bn guidance.

· Divestment target confirmed at $30bn and Shell is actively working on 16 material asset sales.

· Project start-ups in 2016 are expected to add over 250kboe/d to production. New projects from 2014-18 expected to add $10bn of cash flow in 2018 at $60 oil price.

CEO Ben van Beurden – “Shell delivered better results this quarter, reflecting strong operational and cost performance. But lower oil prices continue to be a significant challenge across the business, and the outlook remains uncertain”.

BE

And RBC for a slightly shorter take.

BE

Shell has reported a strong set of results this morning, with adjusted earnings of $2.8bn vs consensus $1.7bn. More importantly, Shell generated
underlying cash flows of $7.8bn, versus organic capex of $7.7bn in the quarter. Gearing has risen to 29.2% from 28.1% last quarter, which appears
to be driven by pension liabilities increasing further. Overall, given the poor result last quarter, we think a number of investors were wary of a
repeat, and this has not occurred. We see room for Shell to outperform its peers in the near term.
Upstream: Production volumes of 3,595kboed were broadly in line with our estimate of 3,580kboed. The upstream was breakeven for the first time in a while,
versus consensus at -$777m. North America remains the largest drag on earnings and generated a loss of $439m, although this was sequentially better by
around $250m.
Downstream: Shell has printed a particularly strong downstream result, with R&M earnings of $1.5bn (consensus $1.4bn) and chemicals earnings of $542m
(consensus $380m).
Guidance: Shell has maintained its 2016 capex guidance at $26bn (cash capex, $29bn gross), whilst also guiding to the bottom end of its 2017 guidance
range $25-30bn. YTD organic capex is running at $20bn, with a $7.7bn figure in Q3, suggesting a slowdown in capex into Q4.

BE

BE

BP actually beats, but it's a tax beat and underlying it's a miss.

BE

Actually, I can't be bothered typing more. Morgan Stanley can do the work.

11:19 am
BE

A 20% earnings beat was flattered by a one-time UK tax
credit, whilst the 16% operating miss was driven by a weak
upstream result. Despite mixed numbers and a modest
increase in gearing, the overall trends in cost/capex savings
and cash flows continues to head in the right direction.

BE

Divisional highlights:
E&P (lower vs. consensus): Underlying replacement cost profit of $(224)m
compared to consensus of $120m. Despite stronger than expected
production 3,140kboe/d vs. MSe 3,088kboe/d, the result was negatively
impacted by rig cancellation fees, higher exploration expense. Further details
expected on the call today at 9am (UK time).
R&M (Higher vs. consensus): Despite weaker refining margins q/q and y/y,
BP delivered adjusted R&M EBIT of $1.4bn vs. consensus of $1.2bn, helped
by strong performance in the retail business and delivery of further cost
efficiency gains.
Rosneft (lower vs. consensus): BP recognised $120m in earnings from
Rosneft, below consensus of $240m driven by less favourable duty lag
effects.
Tax: BP's effective tax rate was -23% in 3Q16 which includes a positive one-
time tax credit relating to the reduction in the rate of the UK North Sea
supplementary charge.

BE

Modest improvement in cash flow q/q but gearing up: BP generated operating
cash flow (excl. working capital changes but incl. Macondo-related payments of
$2.3bn) of $1.8bn in 3Q16. Organic capex was $3.6bn, leaving organic FCF of
$(1.8)bn in 3Q16 compared to $(2.2)bn in 2Q16. Gearing (ND/ND+E) increased
modestly to 25.9% in 3Q16 vs. 24.7% in 2Q16.
2016 and 2017 capex lowered: 2016 capex guidance has now been lowered to
$16bn vs. previous guidance of "below $17bn", whilst BP now expects 2017 capex
to be towards the bottom end of the $15-17bn range previously indicated.
On track to deliver $7bn cash cost reduction target: The company's cash costs
over the past four quarters were $6.1bn lower than in 2014 (an improvement on
~$5.6bn at 2Q16) and leaves BP well-placed to achieve its target of $7bn by
2017.

11:24 am
BE

EBIT of $1.084bn was below consensus of $1.295bn (UBSe $1.419bn). Upstream was
loss-making at -$0.224bn below consensus of +$0.120bn (UBSe +$0.298bn) and
accounted for the EBIT shortfall but was impacted by high expl'n write-offs and rig
cancellation costs. Rosneft posted $0.120bn vs consensus of $0.240bn (UBSe
$0.219bn) on tax duty lag effects. Group production averaged 3,140kboe/d (UBSe
3,218/kboe/d), -3%y/y, of which core BP was 2,110kboe/d (vs UBSe 2,184kboe/d, -6%
y/y on maintenance and GoM interruptions); and Rosneft 1,030kboe/d (UBSe
1,035kboe/d). BP Downstream EBIT was strong at $1.431bn vs consensus $1.24bn
(UBSe of $1.153bn) on good retail earnings and resilient refining. Tax in the quarter
was a credit of $0.164bn as UK tax changes were booked. Despite this accounting
effect, operating cashflows were actually excellent at $4.834bn pre-Macondo vs UBSe
$3.893bn, helped in part by the Rosneft dividend ($332m) but also reflecting the non-
cash effects in E&P EBIT.

BE

2016 capex has been cut to $16bn (previous guidance less than $17bn); suggesting 2017 ($15-17bn) may be lowered at 4Q. 4qtr cash costs are already down $6.1bn (3Q $5.8bn) vs.
the 2017 target of $7bn lower than 2014. The operating cashflow outturn is indicative
of progress and in combination with lower capex helpful in reducing cash neutrality.

BE

Valuation: Neutral, 500p price target
Target corresponds to a 2017E EV/DACF ($60/bbl) of 6.3x, a modest premium to the 3-
year/5-year average, in line with peers Shell and Total.

11:25 am

And there's more evidence today of the non-demand shock of Brexit

PM

Sonali Punhani
-- Credit Suisse

PM

UK manufacturing PMI fell by more than a point to 54.3 in October, but continues to expand at a solid rate.
New orders at 56.7 increased at a pace close to September's 26 month high. Manufacturers reported that the fall in sterling led to an increase in new export business.
Weaker sterling also led to import prices rising by almost 10 points to 80.3, a 69-month peak and its fourth-highest level since the survey began in 1992. This got translated to output prices rising by 5 points to 60.4, the steepest pace since June 2011.
Manufacturing employment increased for the third straight month during October to a one-year high.
The PMI implies that manufacturing is likely to contribute positively to growth in Q4 (even though Q3 manufacturing PMIs overestimated manufacturing growth). The steady growth as well as the inflationary pressures evident from this PMI report imply that the BoE should keep policy on hold in its meeting on Thursday. What would be important in our view is whether they revise their 2017 growth outlook.

PM

Merger complete, new shares start trading – With the completion of the merger, Ladbrokes Coral shares begin trading today with a market capitalisation of some £2.6bn. Our base case scenario, which effectively includes the c£65m of previously announced synergies and the expected recovery in Ladbrokes following the business review announced in July 2015, has EBITDA building to £500m (EPS: 15p) by 2018F from pro-forma £375m (EPS: 10p) LTM. We also present a bull case scenario, which sees the enlarged eliminating the cost and revenue per shop gap with peers and improve its online margin towards 30%, with EBITDA building to c£650m (EPS: 23p). Our analysis suggests that Ladbrokes Coral is worth c180p per share based on our central case assumptions rising to over 220p per share on our Bull case assumptions. At the current price of 134p Ladbrokes Coral trades on 8x 2017F EBITDA, with an implied valuation of 3x EBITDA. We see significant upside from here on all but draconian restrictions on machine play. BUY.

BE

BE

BE

BE

11:37 am
BE

Fifteen months after its initial announcement, the slow motion Ladbrokes/Coral merger finally completed today. We think that it will be worth the wait, notwithstanding increased UK regulatory scrutiny on the Gambling sector. LAD didn't get a compelling valuation (3.6x Ebitda, after adjusting for accrued profits) for its forced sale of 360 stores. But it was a relatively low price to clear a deal that offers strategic value and considerable scale in both retail and Online gambling. It also delivers a strengthened management team and substantial cost synergies, which we see at comfortably above management's projected £65m.
Both LAD and Coral have traded strongly through FY16, supported by a Bookie-friendly European championships, and the early fruits of LAD's strategic review. Online growth remains impressive (Coral +24% in the 3 months ended September, Ladbrokes +33%, albeit from a low base). This strongly underpins post-merger Revenue/Profit expectations. The Triennial review of Stakes/Prizes could drive tighter regulation (i.e. cut the starting point for the so-called £50 journey) or reduce maximum stakes or machine numbers. The impact of the £50 journey was equivalent to a £30m hit to LAD/Coral profits. But we see greater upside to LAD/Coral's £65m synergy targets. This amounts to just 3% of combined 2018 costs, versus 11% for Paddy Power/Betfair and 15% for bwin/party. Clearly, there is less direct overlap in Retail (although management expects 60% of its synergies to come from Retail). But even as a % of just LAD/Coral Online costs, the £65m target is just 9%. A target of over £100m seems realistic.

BE

£100m savings!?! Yeah, right.

BE

We think the fit looks good, and synergies offer upside. This provides plenty of ballast, at a time of increasing uncertainty around UK gambling regulation. And the impact of the deal on forecasts (with just the £65m of synergies) is compelling. We see FY17 EBITA rising from £118.4m to £313.5m, driving EPS up 47% from 7.9p to 11.7p. And given a commitment to 2x dividend cover, the dividend is ramped up to 5.8p. For FY18, EPS is upgraded 65% to 13.9p. Leverage rises, but it remains a comfortable 2.5x Ebitda in FY17F, falling to 2.0x at end FY18F.

11:38 am
BE

Valuation
The shares are off their highs following recent regulatory concerns, but they are still up by 26% over the past year and 14% over 6 months. On our revised forecasts, it trades on a PER of 11.4x and EV/Ebitda of 8.2x (William Hill on 12.7x/8.8x) in FY17 falling to 9.6x and 7.1x in FY18 (a marked discount to Hills on 11.6x/8.2x). And it offers a 4.4% FY17F yield. We think this looks attractive - if we put the Online business on a 12.0x FY17 Ebitda multiple, Retail is valued at just 5.5x. And we see upward pressure on synergies. Our 165p TP (FY17F EV/EBITDA of 9.5x) represents 24% potential upside. BUY.

BE

BE

We've talked rather a lot on here about the extraordinary profit margins price comparison sites seem to be able to deliver, and it usually triggers some email traffic from the feltcollaredsource , so I won't go there again.

11:49 am
BE

Instead, here's Barclays to worry about management having too many levers.

BE

Moneysupermarket’s Q3 trading statement is a mixed bag. On the positive, group revenues are slightly better and management has reiterated guidance for 2016, with the Insurance turnaround on track. The sting in the tail is Money, where growth has slowed to 0% in Q3 (Q1 21%, Q2 14%). Brexit has had an impact, with lower interest rates flowing through into less switching activity in Savings products. Outlook commentary for Money implies revenue declines in Q4, which logically will also flow through into Q1 next year. The benefits of diversification mean that management has a strong track record in pulling different levers to deliver on the overall group numbers. But this is a new thing to worry about.

BE

In Moneysupermarket we see a cheap Internet stock on 16x P/E with a 6% FCF yield in 2017E and a 7.5% dividend yield (split 50 50 regular special) in 2016E that is better invested than its peers and exposed to markets that still have substantial structural growth. But we also see several points of short term uncertainty: 1) the potential for the Insurance switching market to grow less in 2017 than in 2016 if motor premium inflation moderates, 2) the potential for competitor marketing activity to ramp up ahead of a BGL Group IPO sometime next year (FT, Sep 18 2016), 3) a new CEO who could bring tweaks to the strategy and doesn’t start until next year, 4) Money growth if there are any further side effects of Brexit, 5) the impact of the weaker GBP on Travel. Remain EW, 320p PT.

11:50 am
BE

Highlights of Q3 trading: Group revenue growth is slightly better than anticipated with 12% growth in Q3 ahead of our +9%. The turnaround in Insurance continues (+12% vs our +8%) and Home Services continues to deliver remarkable numbers (+44% vs our +20%). Money grew 0% in Q3 (we had 13%) and Travel declined 4% (we had -20%). The body of this note contains a detailed review of each division, with particular explanation of the moving parts within Money. Management has said it remains happy with market expectations of £106m of EBITA in 2016E (in line with our expectations).
Changes to forecasts: We make only small changes to forecasts. We have slightly extra revenue and slightly extra cost, with EPS up 1% in 2016 and 1% in 2017.
Valuation attractive: Shares are on 16x P/E in 2017, with a 6% FCF yield. The regular divi is 4% and we forecast another 4% special this year, taking the total to 7.5%.

BE

Back to STAN. And it turns out that after approximately one vaguely reassuring quarter, the turnaround has stalled.

BE

Revenue misses.

11:57 am
BE

Citi incoming.

BE

STAN 3Q16 PBT of $153m on a statutory basis and $458m underlying is below our expectations. Revenues excluding an OCA adjustment of $3.5bn was 3% better than our forecast and in-line with cons. Costs (including restructuring) of $2.4bn are in-line with our and cons expectations. A loan loss of $704m (underlying $596m and restructuring $108m) is the main variance versus our forecast of $572m. 3Q16 CET1 was below expectations but the 4Q16 guidance is positive.

BE

C&I revenues of $1.6bn are up +2% qoq and 4% better than Citi expectations, albeit they are still down -7% yoy. Financial Markets revenues increased by +15% yoy (+11% qoq), with higher primary and secondary activity part offset by lower FX. In contrast Transaction Banking revenues fell by -10% yoy (but +3% qoq). Average Trade margins were stable qoq, while Cash margins increased slightly. Meanwhile Corporate Finance revenues fell by -19% yoy (-11% qoq) on a delay in the deal pipeline.

11:58 am
BE

3Q16 saw a qoq uptick in loan losses to $704m, on heavier restructuring, but this remains well below the 3Q-4Q15 levels. On the ‘ongoing business’ the NPL + CG12 ratio has increased from 2.7% to 2.9% qoq and coverage ratio increased from 62% to 63%. The liquidation portfolio has shrunk by a further 3% qoq to $7.1bn loans and $19bn RWAs, with progress since 4Q16 expected to reduce NPLs by $2.6bn and RWAs by $13.2bn, improving coverage on the liquidation portfolio from 46% to up to 60%.

BE

CET1 declined to 13.0% from 13.1% end 1H16 (below our 13.2% forecast) but the company are guiding an addition c50bps CET1 due to “recently completed and further restructuring actions” ahead of our 13.3% forecast. We believe this is due to the reduction in the high RWA density Liquidation portfolio which is successfully being sold down, part offset by further restructuring costs ($2.1bn of total $3.0bn booked so far). We have $843m of restructuring charges in for 4Q16

BE

While at first glance the 3Q16 results appear below our and market expectations, the main negatives – asset quality and lower CET1 – will likely improve in 4Q16. Revenues and cost trends are on-track versus our expectations.

BE

We downgrade MRW to Hold to reflect the equity's sharp rerating YTD. We
do not exclude the potential for more material upside further down the
line. However, this requires the ability to construct a more positive industry
narrative than we currently feel possible. MRW remains best positioned vs
UK peers given B/S, FC conversion and vertical integration at a time when
heightened inflation could pose a new industry challenge.

BE

An exciting YTD... has seen MRW outperform FTSE by greater than 40%, and the shares rerate to cal 2017 P/E of greater than 18x, EV/EBITDA of 7.3x and FCY of c.8%. Headline valuation ignores the re-leverage option, which could benefit shareholders in the mid-term (given adj net debt/EBITDAR falling to 1.4x by 18/19).

...followed by an uneventful Q3 where we assume Q3 LFL gains of 1.2%. The business
continues to outperform peers as in-store standards remain on an improving trend. While
the Fresh Look programme intensified in Q3, we would expect a largely neutral balance of
pre refurb disruption and post reinvestment sales uplifts.
